Refer to diabetes medication review documentation completed with MedsCheck for Diabetes (ON)/Diabetes SMMA (AB)/Diabetes Medication Review (PEI) for patient and prescriber information.
Background Information to Initiate Conversation with Patient.
Diabetic retinopathy is the most common cause of incident blindness (legal) in people of working age and often goes unnoticed until vision loss occurs. High sugar levels cause the blood vessels to swell and leak into the retina and cause blurred vision or blind spots. If left untreated, new blood vessels may grow and cause further damage to your vision. With good glycemic control, regular eye exams and early treatment, the risk of vision loss is reduced.

If 'Yes,' at what stage of readiness is the patient? {{#if hasPrecontemplation}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}} Precontemplation {{#if hasContemplation}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}} Contemplation {{#if hasPreparation}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}} Preparation {{#if hasMaintenance}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}} Action {{#if hasAction}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}} Maintenance {{/if}} {{/if}}
PHARMACIST’S GOAL(S) OF THERAPY FOR EYE HEALTH
{{#if GoTResponse}} {{#if goalsOfTherapyReduceRiskDevelopment}}☑ Reduce risk of the development of diabetic retinopathy.
{{/if}} {{#if goalsOfTherapyReduceRiskProgression}}☑ Reduce risk of the progression of diabetic retinopathy, including blindness.
{{/if}} {{#if goalsOfTherapyReduceRiskMorbidity}}☑ Reduce risk of morbidity and mortality associated with diabetic retinopathy.
{{/if}} {{#if goalsOfTherapyOther}}{{#if goalsOfTherapyOther}}☑{{else}}☐{{/if}}Other: {{goalsOfTherapyOtherPleaseSpecify}}{{/if}} {{else}} There haven't been any goals of therapy for eye health selected. {{/if}}
ASSESSMENT/DRUG THERAPY PROBLEM(S)
{{#if DTPResponse}} {{#if riskDevelopmentProgressionDrugTherapyModification}}☑ Patient is at risk of development or progression of diabetic retinopathy and requires drug therapy modification to reduce the risk (i.e. glycemic control, blood pressure control, lipid-lowering therapy)
{{/if}} {{#if sightThreateningDiabetic}}☑ Patient has sight-threatening diabetic retinopathy and requires assessment by ophthalmologist/retina specialist.
{{/if}} {{#if visuallyDisabled}}☑ Patient is visually disabled and requires referral for low-vision evaluation and rehabilitation.

text.en: Review
Please ensure that this information is reviewed and submitted by an individual authorized to provide MedsCheck services to patients.
Please ensure that the patient's Ontario Drug Benefit details are updated prior to creating the documentation
Information added or modified on this form will not automatically update the patient's profile in HealthWATCH. Navigate to the patient's profile to update all necessary fields.
Please click here to report any errors or provide any feedback. You can also rate the form here.

text.en: Suggested Speaking Points

innerHTML.en:
Suggested Speaking Points:
• Exercise and healthy eating are essential for managing diabetes.
• Physical activity improves blood sugar control, aids in weight loss, and offers various health benefits.
• A healthy diet not only improves diabetes management but also enhances overall health and prevents complications like heart and kidney disease

label.en: Does the patient have a physical activity regimen that includes the recommended following?

innerHTML.en:
Does the patient have a physical activity regimen that includes the recommended following?

• At least 150 minutes per week of moderate- to vigorous-intensity aerobic exercise, ideally spread over at least 3 days of the week, with no more than 2 consecutive days without exercise (e.g., walking, jogging, cycling, etc.).
• In addition to aerobic exercise, at least 2 sessions per week of strength/resistance training (e.g., exercises with weights), preferably 3 times per week.

Recommend the handy portion guide as a starting point for nutrition counselling. When planning a meal, use the following portion sizes as a

innerHTML.en: Recommend the handy portion guide as a starting point for nutrition counselling. When planning a meal, use the following portion sizes as a {{dietGuide}}

• Grains and starches/fruits: choose an amount the size of your fist for grains or starches, or fruit.
• Milk and alternatives: drink up to 1 cup (250 mL) of low-fat milk with a meal.
• Vegetables: choose as much as you can hold in both hands, and choose brightly coloured vegetables (e.g., green or yellow beans, broccoli, etc.).
• Meat and alternatives: choose an amount the size of the palm of your hand and the thickness of your little finger.
• Fat: limit fat to an amount the size of the tip of your thumb.

text.en: Signs and Symptoms of HYPOGlycemia

innerHTML.en:
Neurogenic/automic symptoms Neuroglycopenic symptoms
• Sweating
• Trembling
• Hunger
• Nausea
• Tingling
• Anxiety
• Palpitations/Increased heart rate 		• Weakness/dizziness/drowsiness
• Headache
• Confusion
• Difficulty concentrating/speaking
• Vision changes
• Sleep disturbances
• Seizure
• Loss of consciousness


Mild to moderate HYPOglycemia (blood glucose ≥ 2.8 mmol/L, symptoms present, able to self-treat) Follow the “15-15 rule”:

Ingest 15 g of carbohydrate.
Wait 15 minutes and recheck blood sugar.
If blood sugar still low, repeat steps 1 and 2; otherwise, eat a snack (starch + protein) or next meal if within an hour.
Conscious and severe HYPOglycemia (blood glucose < 2.8 mmol/L, symptoms present) Ingest 20 g of carbohydrate:

Wait 15 minutes and recheck blood sugar.
If blood sugar still low, repeat steps 1 and 2; otherwise, eat a snack (starch + protein) or next meal if within an hour.
Unconscious and severe HYPOglycemia (blood glucose < 2.8 mmol/L) A caregiver or support person should administer 1 mg of glucagon under the skin or in the muscle by injection and call for emergency services immediately.

innerHTML.en:
Suggested Speaking Points:
The combination of high blood sugar and smoking dramatically increases damage to the blood vessels that feed the heart, brain, eyes, kidneys, and peripheral nerves, speeding up the long-term complications of diabetes (e.g., heart attack, stroke, kidney problems, etc.).

Quitting smoking is one of the most important things people with diabetes can do to help prevent or delay the onset of complications.

text.en: Counselled patient on key takeaways from Canada’s low-risk alcohol drinking guidelines (Aug 2022) below:

innerHTML.en:
1. All levels of alcohol consumption are associated with some risk, so drinking less is better for everyone.
2. Among healthy individuals, there is a continuum of risk for alcohol-related harms whereby the risk is :
    • Negligible to low for individuals who consume two standard drinks or less per week .
    • Moderate for those who consume between three and six standard drinks per week; and
    • Increasingly high for those who consume more than six standard drinks per week.
3. On any occasion, any level of consumption has risks, and with more than two standard drinks, most individuals will have an increased risk of injuries or other problems.
4. Disproportionately more injuries, violence, and deaths will result of men`s drinking.
5.Above low levels of alcohol consumption, the health risks increase more steeply for women than men
6.It is sagest not to drink alcohol while pregnant and during the preconception period
7.For women who are breastfeeding, it is safest not to use alcohol-related.

Age, Underlying Condition Type of Vaccine Number of doses and recommended schedule
• Immunocompetent adults 18 to less than 65 years of age at high risk of IPD due to an underlying medical condition • Pneu-P-23 • 1 dose +
• 1 booster dose of Pneu-P-23 vaccine at least 5 years later for people at highest risk of IPD

For adults who received Pneu-P-23 vaccine before 65 years of age, an additional dose of Pneu-P-23 vaccine should be administered at least 5 years after any previous dose.
• Adults with an immunocompromising condition (except HSCT) • Pneu-C-13

innerHTML.en: Is the Patient up-to-date on their Meningococcal vaccine?

• Recommend meningococcal (Men-C-C or Men-C-ACYW) vaccine for adolescents and young adults (12-24 years of age) if they have not received it, even if previously they have been vaccinated as an infant or toddler.
• Recommend meningococcal (Men-C-ACYW) vaccine for adults with any of the following:

- Acquired complement deficiencies [e.g., receiving eculizumab (Soliris™)]
- Asplenia (functional or anatomic)
- Cochlear implant recipients (pre/post-implant)
- Complement, properdin, factor D, or primary antibody deficiencies
- HIV

Refer to {{VaccineMeningococcalLink}} on Meningococcal vaccine for information on booster doses and re-immunization.

label.en: Notes (e.g. Approximate date of vaccination, other clinically relevant information):
Is the Patient up-to-date on their Hepatitis B vaccine?

innerHTML.en: Is the Patient up-to-date on their Hepatitis B vaccine?

• Recommend HB vaccine if any of the below apply (publicly funded doses in brackets) and they have not received it (titres may be required):

- Household and sexual contacts of chronic carriers and acute cases (3 doses)
- History of a sexually transmitted disease (3 doses)
- Intravenous drug use (3 doses)
- Liver disease (chronic), including hepatitis C (3 doses)
- Awaiting liver transplants (2nd and 3rd doses only)
- Men who have sex with men (3 doses)
- Multiple sex partners (3 doses)
- Needle stick injuries in a non-health care setting (3 doses)
- On renal dialysis or those with diseases requiring frequent receipt of blood products (e.g., haemophilia) (2nd and 3rd doses only)

• Refer to {{VaccineHepatitisBLink}} on Hepatitis B vaccine for recommendations for use.

• With the exception of people with chronic renal failure and some immunocompromising conditions who require a higher dosage of HB antigen, adults with indications for immunization against both HA and HB should receive HAHB vaccine (see next section).

selectionCount.fail: We need you to pick more options.
selectionCount.pass: You've picked as many as we need you to.

label.en: Notes (e.g. Approximate date of vaccination, other clinically relevant information):
Is the Patient up-to-date on their Hepatitis A vaccine?

innerHTML.en: Is the Patient up-to-date on their Hepatitis A vaccine?

• Recommend HA vaccine for those at increased risk of infection or severe HA:

- Travellers to HA-endemic countries
- Individuals living in communities at risk of HA outbreaks or in which HA is endemic
- Household or close contacts of children adopted from HA-endemic countries
- Men who have sex with men (MSM) (publicly funded)
- Injectable and non-injectable illicit drug users (publicly funded)
- Workers involved in research on HA virus or production of HA vaccine who may be exposed to HA virus
- Military personnel and humanitarian relief workers who are likely to be posted to areas with high rates of HA
- Zoo-keepers, veterinarians, and researchers who handle non-human primates
- People receiving repeated replacement of plasma-derived clotting factors
- Individuals with chronic liver disease, including hepatitis B and C (publicly funded)
- Individuals over 60 years of age

• With the exception of people with chronic renal failure and some immunocompromising conditions who require a higher dosage of HB antigen, adults with indications for immunization against both HA and HB should receive HAHB vaccine.

• People who wish to decrease their risk of acquiring HA should also be encouraged to be vaccinated.

label.en: Notes (e.g. Approximate date of vaccination, other clinically relevant information):
Is the Patient up-to-date on their Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine?

innerHTML.en: Is the Patient up-to-date on their Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccine?

• Recommend Hib vaccine for those if any of the following apply and they have not received it after the age of 5 years:

- Congenital (primary) immunodeficiency
- Malignant hematologic disorders
- HIV
- Anatomic or functional asplenia (including sickle cell disease)
- All transplant recipients
- Cochlear transplant recipients

Consultation with the patient’s primary care provider or an infectious disease expert is advised.

innerHTML.en: Is the Patient up-to-date on their Pertussis (ap) vaccine?

• Recommend Pertussis-containing vaccine (e.g., Tdap) for all adults if they did not receive a dose in adulthood.
• Recommend a Tdap vaccine to all pregnant women in every pregnancy, irrespective of their immunization history. One dose of Tdap vaccine should ideally be provided between 27 and 32 weeks of gestation.

innerHTML.en:
Suggested Speaking Points: when traveling outside Canada, you may be at risk for a number of vaccine preventable illnesses. We can book an in-person or telephone travel consultation ideally at least six weeks before you travel. This is an opportunity to:
  • Review how to manage your diabetes while you are travelling (e.g., medication and testing supplies, medication administration times, hypoglycemia prevention strategies, etc.)
  • Review your immunization history
  • Make sure your provincial/territorial vaccination schedule is up to date
  • Discuss any trip-related health concerns you may have
  • Assess your needs based on where you plan to travel and what you plan to do
You may need additional vaccinations depending on your age, planned travel activities, and local conditions.
  • Consider referring {{vaccLink3}}.
  • Consider scheduling a follow-up travel consultation.

innerHTML.en:
Diabetes Education Follow Ups

The topics marked “Suggested” have been identified for follow-up education opportunities for the Patient based on the initial Diabetes MedsCheck. Please use professional judgment to determine the appropriate follow-up topics that will be added to the Patient's Care Plan, and as agreed upon by the patient. Add topics to Patient’s Personalized Care Plan by selecting “Add to Plan” under each desired topic. Use the MedMe booking link to schedule appointments for Pharmacist Care Consultations to discuss the identified topics, as appropriate. Following appointment booking, enter the date(s) under the corresponding topics by selecting “Record Date of Appointment”.

In the tables, "Not Scheduled" refers to a Diabetes Education Consultation or an A1C test conducted for Patient that was not added to the original Care Plan, but has been added following discussion with the patient and based on the Patient’s need.

Note: If you are not currently logged into MedMe, you will be asked to login, then return to this page and click the booking link again to access the booking flow.
